journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Does Double-Row Rotator Cuff Repair Improve Functional Outcome of Patients Compared With Single-Row Technique?
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review

article-meta.aff: *Department of Orthopaedic Surgery and Sports Medicine, Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, Massachusetts
Investigation performed at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery and Sports Medicine, Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, Massachusetts

author-notes.corresp: †Timothy E. Foster, MD, Boston University School of Medicine, 720 Harrison Avenue, Suite 808, Boston, MA 02481 (e-mail: Timothy.Foster@bmc.org).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

abstract.p: Background: The advantage of single-row versus double-row arthroscopic rotator cuff repair techniques has been a controversial issue in sports medicine and shoulder surgery. There is biomechanical evidence that double-row techniques are superior to single-row techniques; however, there is no clinical evidence that the double-row technique provides an improved functional outcome.

Hypothesis: When compared with single-row rotator cuff repair, double-row fixation, although biomechanically superior, has no clinical benefit with respect to retear rate or improved functional outcome.

Methods: The authors reviewed prospective studies of level I or II clinical evidence that compared the efficacy of single- and double-row rotator cuff repairs. Functional outcome scores included the American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) shoulder scale, the Constant shoulder score, and the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) shoulder rating scale. Radiographic failures and complications were also analyzed. A test of heterogeneity for patient demographics was also performed to determine if there were differences in the patient profiles across the included studies.

Results: Seven studies fulfilled our inclusion criteria. The test of heterogeneity across these studies showed no differences. The functional ASES, Constant, and UCLA outcome scores revealed no difference between single- and double-row rotator cuff repairs. The total retear rate, which included both complete and partial retears, was 43.1% for the single-row repair and 27.2% for the double-row repair (P = .057), representing a trend toward higher failures in the single-row group.

Conclusion: Through a comprehensive literature search and meta-analysis of current arthroscopic rotator cuff repairs, we found that the single-row repairs did not differ from the double-row repairs in functional outcome scores. The double-row repairs revealed a trend toward a lower radiographic proven retear rate, although the data did not reach statistical significance. There may be a concerning trend toward higher retear rates in patients undergoing a single-row repair, but further studies are required.

body.p: A tear of the rotator cuff is one of the most common disorders of the shoulder and can have a significant effect on daily activities as a result of a loss of motion and strength. Rotator cuff tears have been associated with both intrinsic and extrinsic factors: impingement from a curved, hooked, or laterally sloped acromion4,23,31,33; degenerative changes from microtrauma and mechanical overuse33; and as a result of the natural aging process.41,45 It is also associated with alterations in the metabolic environment of the tendon, particularly in relation to tobacco use14,24,33 and diabetes mellitus.8,33 While rotator cuff tears are a common condition seen by physicians, the true incidence of this disorder is unknown. This is because of a high rate of asymptomatic tears that may be present in 20% to 50% of adults over the age of 60 years29,37,41 and in 80% of adults over the age of 80 years.29,41

Although nonoperative therapy is regarded as first-line treatment for the majority of rotator cuff tears, surgical intervention is indicated when nonoperative treatment is unsuccessful. The goal of rotator cuff repair is to treat the patient’s current clinical symptoms and improve shoulder function and to prevent the long-term consequences of rotator cuff arthropathy.11,30 Gerber et al15 proposed that an ideal rotator cuff repair would have high initial fixation strength, permit minimal gap formation, and sustain mechanical stability until healing has occurred.

The evolution of rotator cuff repair has progressed over the past 2 decades with the advent of arthroscopic techniques. Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair can provide a strong biomechanical construct, while at the same time providing improved patient satisfaction and a decrease in postoperative complications. An open surgical approach to rotator cuff tears has been associated with an increase in postoperative complications due to deltoid injury, scarring, adhesive capsulitis, and pain.40 The mini-open approach improved the postoperative outcome, likely as a result of limited soft tissue dissection.40 Arthroscopy has gained significant popularity as a method of treating rotator cuff tears, evolving from tendon debridement to full repair of a torn rotator cuff with minimal soft tissue disruption.21

Currently, there are 2 common arthroscopic techniques that are employed for repairing rotator cuff tears. The first technique, single-row fixation, involves passing sutures through the lateral aspect of the torn cuff and repairing the tendon to the humeral head footprint as a single row of fixation. This is accomplished through bone tunnels or with the use of suture anchors. The clinical results of single-row fixation have been good,9,19,20,35 with retear rates reported by some authors as low as 19%.19

Biomechanical and cadaveric studies have uncovered potential problems with single-row repair. Specifically, this repair restores only 67% of the original footprint of the rotator cuff.1 Apreleva et al suggested that a larger contact area between the tendon and bone might allow more fibers to participate in the healing process, leading to a more stable repair.1 Lo and Burkhart21 subsequently developed a double-row repair technique, with one anchor placed medially and the tails of the sutures then brought laterally to compress the free tendon onto the remaining insertion site. They proposed that this would restore a greater area of the anatomic footprint, increase the strength of the repair construct, and decrease the stress at each suture loop and anchor. They surmised that this would result in an increase rate of healing. Biomechanical studies have supported the double-row repair, confirming that this technique increases the anatomic restoration of the rotator cuff tendon.5,25,27,32,43 Several authors have demonstrated the resilience of this repair in the laboratory. Specifically, gap formation was less,3,17,22,28,38 and they noted an increased number of cycles to failure.26,38,44 While these results are impressive, there is a lack of clinical evidence that suggests double-row techniques result in better functional outcomes and fewer complications than single-row repair.2,6,13,16,18

There are several retrospective studies in the medical literature reporting on the results of single- and double-row repairs. Recent studies, however, have compared the 2 methods against one another in a prospective manner.2,6,7,13,16,18,34 Each individual study has failed to come to a strong conclusion with regard to the superiority or indication for one of the 2 repair methods. In hopes of clarifying this issue, we conducted a systematic review of all level I and II studies that evaluated functional scores, objective data, and/or radiographic outcomes to compare the efficacy of single- versus double-row rotator cuff repair techniques. Our belief is that double-row rotator cuff repair, although biomechanically superior to single-row fixation, has no clinical benefit with respect to a lower retear rate or improved functional outcome.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: The primary objective was to perform a systematic review to evaluate the functional and radiographic outcomes of single- and double-row rotator cuff repairs. All abstracts of single- or double-row rotator cuff repairs were reviewed. Article identification was performed by searches on Ovid Medline and PubMed, using search criteria of “single row rotator cuff repair AND outcome” or “double row rotator cuff repair AND outcome.” The searches were performed in February of 2009 and again in April of 2011. An extensive bibliography search was conducted of all the articles that were identified. Additionally, we searched major sports medicine journals along with the “related articles” element in PubMed. The articles were compared with our inclusion and exclusion criteria to see which could be used for the study.
Inclusion criteria:

list-item.p: Study includes both double- and single-row repairs
Follow-up examination presenting at least one of the outcome measurements: ASES score, Constant score, or UCLA scale

sec.p: Exclusion criteria:

list-item.p: Report efficacy of only single- or only double-row repairs
Studies that included open or mini-open procedures

sec.title: Evaluation
sec.p: Both subjective and objective functional outcome measurements were used in evaluating the data. The Constant shoulder score10; University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) shoulder rating scale12; and American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) shoulder scale36 were those analyzed to determine functional outcome. Additionally, radiographic follow-up of repaired rotator cuffs and reported intraoperative and postoperative complications were analyzed for differences between the 2 groups. If the studies reported several functional outcome scores at different follow-up visits, the score at final follow-up was used for the study.

sec.title: Functional Outcome Scores
sec.p: The ASES shoulder scale is a subjective measurement of shoulder function.36 The score is scaled from 0 to 100 and is divided into 2 categories: pain and level of function. The Constant shoulder score combines subjective and objective data into a functional score on a scale of 0 to 100.1 The UCLA shoulder rating scale uses subjective and objective measurements in evaluating shoulder function on a scale of 0 to 35.12

sec.title: Radiographic Proven Retears
sec.p: A rotator cuff repair is considered a failure when there is objective evidence of a persistent defect or retear of the rotator cuff; however, this specific radiographic finding may or may not be correlated with an alteration in the functional outcome. Radiographic failures were determined at or before final follow-up by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), magnetic resonance arthrography, or computed tomography (CT) arthrography. Retears were analyzed in 2 groups: (1) complete retears and (2) partial-thickness retears involving the entire repair or a portion of the repair.

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: Any intraoperative or postoperative complication mentioned in the article was analyzed and added as a complication. This includes wound problems, adhesive capsulitis, iatrogenic fracture, suture problems, and radiographic proven retears.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: A test of heterogeneity for patient demographics and rotator cuff tears was performed to determine if there were differences in the patient profile between single and double repair groups across the included studies. Independent t tests or χ2 tests were performed as appropriate. P values <.05 were considered statistically significant. Summary data (mean demographics, functional scores, failure rates) for single- and double-row repairs were extracted from each study, and the difference between the single and double groups was computed. For the functional scores and failure rates, this difference was then weighted by the inverse of the variance around the means and from these weighted mean differences a pooled average difference using all the studies was computed. The z statistic was used to test whether a pooled average difference was equal to zero. The statistical methods were evaluated and approved by a professional statistician.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Literature searches of the 2 databases resulted in 22 citations. Further analysis of the related articles, article citations, and major sports medicine journals resulted in over 200 potential abstracts. Of these citations, nearly 40 studies were identified that reviewed the topic of interest, with only 7 studies fitting all of the inclusion criteria.2,6,7,13,16,18,34 The 7 studies contained a total of 226 patients in the single-row repair group and 220 patients in the double-row repair group.

The majority of the articles that were excluded (29 studies) were because of the level of evidence. These studies included single-row techniques only (23 studies), double-row techniques only (4 studies), or single versus double (2 studies). One level II single-row technique study was excluded because of a lack of a comparison group. Two articles that only included workers’ compensation patients were excluded as well.

sec.title: Patient Demographics
sec.p: A test of heterogeneity was performed to determine if there were any differences in patient profiles or types of rotator cuff tears across the 7 studies. Patient demographics and specific information related to the rotator cuff tear can be found in Table 1. The test of heterogeneity, seen in Table 2, compared those who were repaired with the double-row technique with those who were repaired with the single-row technique across the 7 studies. It showed that there were no significant differences with respect to the demographic or rotator cuff tear profile between those who underwent repair with either technique. The surgical techniques, tear size, number of suture anchors, and rehabilitation protocols varied slightly across the 7 included studies; these differences are highlighted in Table 3.

fn.label: a
fn.p: “Dominant, %” correlates with the percentage of rotator cuff tears occurring on the patient’s dominant arm.

fn.label: b
fn.p: “Mean preoperative time, mo” represents the average time from onset of symptoms until the date of surgery.

fn.label: c
fn.p: “Mean postoperative time, mo” corresponds with the length of follow-up after surgery.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Positive differences mean double > single. Negative differences mean double < single.

sec.title: Functional Scores
sec.p: Three of the studies reported results of the ASES shoulder score,6,18,34 6 studies evaluated the Constant shoulder score,2,6,7,16,18,34 and 3 studies included the UCLA shoulder score.6,13,18 Table 4 documents the preoperative and postoperative scores for each study. There were no significant differences between single- and double-row repairs. The preoperative and postoperative differences were determined as double-row scores minus single-row scores, such that positive numbers reflect the double-row score being higher, while negative numbers reflect the single-row score being higher.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Standard deviation in parentheses unless otherwise stated.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Positive differences mean double > single. Negative differences mean double < single.

fn.label: c
fn.p: 95% confidence interval (CI) in parentheses. Difference between treatments not significant if 95% CI contains zero.

sec.p: The mean preoperative and postoperative functional scores for both repair methods were used to determine the amount of functional improvement at final follow-up (Table 5). The weighted averages of all 3 outcome scores found no statistical difference in patients who were repaired by the double-row technique versus the single-row technique when comparing preoperative and postoperative functional scores.

caption.p: Differences in Preoperative and Postoperative Functional Scoresa

fn.label: a
fn.p: Standard deviation in parentheses unless otherwise stated.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Positive differences mean double > single. Negative differences mean double < single.

fn.label: c
fn.p: 95% confidence interval (CI) in parentheses. Difference between treatments not significant if 95% CI contains zero.

sec.title: Radiographic Failures
sec.p: Four studies documented the incidence of retears at or before final follow-up.6,7,13,18 Imaging consisted of MRI,6,18 magnetic resonance arthrography,13 or CT arthrography.7 The incidence of partial-thickness retears is reported in Table 6. Overall, the single-row repair group had a 4.7% increased rate of complete rotator cuff retears at final follow-up (weighted difference, 2.6%), which was not statistically significant (P = .57). When partial retears are included, the single-row fixation group had a 15.9% higher retear rate (weighted difference, 12.1%; P = .057). While not statistically significant, the trend was toward a decreased retear rate for patients undergoing a double-row repair.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Double row – single row. Positive difference indicates double row > single row. Negative difference indicates double row < single row.

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: In addition to the radiographic information documenting retear rate, 4 of the 7 studies noted intraoperative and postoperative complications.2,7,13,34 There were no intraoperative complications in either group, while there were 6 postoperative complications in the single-row group and 4 complications in the double-row group. These included 5 cases of adhesive capsulitis (3 in single row, 2 in double row), 2 cases of suture anchor failure (1 in single row, 1 in double row), 2 cases of postoperative infection (both single row), and 1 case of delayed wound healing (double row). Final analysis, with retears included, identified 56 complications (of 186 patients) in the single-row repair group and 35 complications (of 180 patients) in the double-row repair group. The weighted differences between the studies found a 1.5% increased complication rate for the single-row technique when the retears were not included (P = .52) and a 3.0% increased complication rate when retears were included (P = .35).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The evolution in the treatment of rotator cuff disease has progressed rapidly in the past 20 years. New techniques have resulted in arthroscopic approaches, improved fixation devices, and several methods of fixation. Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair is frequently performed; however, there are few prospective studies that evaluate which method of arthroscopic repair has improved functional outcome scores and fewer failures. Our review of the literature and subsequent meta-analysis has found that repair through both single- and double-row fixation methods results in significant improvements in functional outcome scores. Although patients who underwent double-row fixation tended to have higher functional outcome scores postoperatively, the data are not statistically significant and it may not be clinically significant. The double-row repairs had a trend toward a lower retear rate, but the data did not reach statistical significance.

sec.title: Radiographic Analysis
sec.p: In our investigation, radiographic failures, deemed as a partial or complete retear at or before final follow-up, were recorded in 4 studies.6,7,13,18 Three different methods were used to determine the retear rate: 2 used MRI, 1 used magnetic resonance arthrography, and 1 used CT arthrography. When combining the 4 studies, we found a trend toward a higher retear rate, including complete and partial-thickness tears in patients who had single-row fixation. Complete retears alone had a 4.7% higher incidence (weighted difference, 2.6%) in the single-row group, while partial-thickness retears had a 15.9% higher occurrence (weighted average, 12.1%); although this may represent a trend the data did not reach statistical significance.

The study by Koh et al18 interestingly showed a trend for a higher complete retear rate for the double-row fixation group, but when partial tears were analyzed as well, they found the single-row repair was significantly inferior (P = .041). Charousset et al7 did not specifically analyze statistics for retear rates of complete and partial tears. However, through CT arthrography, they were able to conclude that anatomic healing was significantly superior in the double-row fixation group (P = .03).

sec.title: Functional Score Analysis
sec.p: The greater clinical importance between these 2 surgical approaches lies in the functional scores seen after a rotator cuff repair. The functional scores take into account many important aspects in a patient’s daily life, such as range of motion, function, strength, pain, and satisfaction, and serve as the most useful way to evaluate patient outcome. Each individual study analyzed in this meta-analysis found no significant differences in functional score improvements between single- and double-row repairs. Some scores showed a trend toward increased improvement for the single-row technique, while others favored the double row, leading to the mixed conclusions in the literature.

Through our meta-analysis of the functional scores from the 7 listed studies, 2 things were readily apparent. The first, which is the same conclusion from each included article, is that all patients who underwent repair with either the single- or double-row technique improved significantly. The second issue is that those who had double-row fixation did not have a significant improvement in function. The raw postoperative scores trended higher for double-row fixation, but they did not reach statistical significance, and a recent study discovered that an improvement in the ASES score by 12 to 17 points was required for a patient to notice functional benefit in daily life.39 Thus, there is no evidence that a double-row repair provides superior postoperative functional outcome scores compared with single-row techniques.

These articles are all prospective in nature and used both single- and double-row techniques to repair tears of all sizes. Only one article discussed differences in functional scores between single- and double-row techniques when tears were analyzed as less than or greater than 3 cm. The study by Park et al34 found that when all tears were analyzed together, there were no significant differences in final clinical outcome scores between those who underwent single- or double-row fixation. Similarly, when analyzed by tears less than 3 cm, there was no difference in functional scores. However, they found that tears greater than 3 cm had significantly better outcomes (P < .05) in all 3 of the above measures for double-row repair. Koh et al18 reported a similar opinion that small rotator cuff tears do not require double-row fixation but that it is the large rotator cuff tears that may be ideal for double-row fixation.

A direction of future studies could be to analyze single- versus double-row repairs on tears less than or greater than 3 cm to determine if the size of the index tear truly influences functional or radiographic outcome. The method of double-row fixation may also be of importance; the initial double-row technique involved the use of a medial and lateral row of suture anchors. A transosseous equivalent (TOE) has been introduced, which uses a medial row of suture anchors and a lateral row of knotless anchors, utilizing the suture limbs from the medial row to compress the rotator cuff against the anatomic footprint. A recent article by Toussaint et al42 suggests excellent functional results with a low retear rate using the TOE. Similarly, documentation of tendon quality at the time of repair, along with clinical and radiographic follow-up, could provide further insight into the effects of the different repair methods. To detect a statistically significant difference in ASES score among groups, where one group improves by 17 points greater than the others,39 a randomized trial with 80% power would need at least 26 patients in each group. This assumes the correlation between the preoperative and postoperative scores is modest (r = .50). Similarly, using an average complete tear rate of 18% observed in the published studies, 247 patients would be needed per group to detect a statistically significant difference of 9% (or a reduction by half) among groups, and 1072 patients per group would be needed to detect a difference of 4.5% (or a reduction by one fourth).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our results indicate that arthroscopic double-row rotator cuff repair does not yield higher functional outcome scores or a lower postoperative complication rate compared with single-row rotator cuff repairs. There was a trend in the double-row repair groups toward a lower retear rate when considering both complete retears and partial-thickness retears, although the data did not reach statistical significance. The future evaluation of prospective studies with a larger number of patients, and directed at tears of a specific size and tendon quality, may make the trends identified in this study more apparent. This study evaluated double-row rotator cuff repairs; it did not specifically evaluate transosseous equivalent double-row repairs, and future study is required to determine if these techniques provide different results.

boxed-text.p: An online CME course associated with this article is available for 1 AMA PRA Category 1 Credit™ at http://ajsm-cme.sagepub.com. In accordance with the standards of the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), it is the policy of The American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine that authors, editors, and planners disclose to the learners all financial relationships during the past 12 months with any commercial interest (A ‘commercial interest’ is any entity producing, marketing, re-selling, or distributing health care goods or services consumed by, or used on, patients). Any and all disclosures are provided in the online journal CME area which is provided to all participants before they actually take the CME activity. In accordance with AOSSM policy, authors, editors, and planners’ participation in this educational activity will be predicated upon timely submission and review of AOSSM disclosure. Noncompliance will result in an author/editor or planner to be stricken from participating in this CME activity.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
